tobiko/openstack/heat/_stack.py.message: if You are not waiting until stack will be created, isn't it possible that some VMs will still don't have IP addresses assigned when You will check them so test may fail because of that?

Slawek,
In order to reproduce the bug BZ#2124877 we need to add some nasty things in this test, unfortunately. This is because we need to trigger some unlikely race condition.
The way to reproduce this issue is to send the creation of N VMs and, after a few seconds, without waiting for their complete creation, to reboot a controller.

As you say, this could make impossible for some VMs to obtain their IPs.
We tested this several times and we came to the conclusion that when an VMs don't receive its port/IPs, its status is BUILD for some time, but it eventually becomes ERROR.
We wait until VMs change from BUILD to either ERROR or ACTIVE in the function get_vms_detailed_info: https://review.opendev.org/c/x/tobiko/+/869339/8/tobiko/tests/faults/ha/cloud_disruptions.py#318

The test doesn't check that all the VMs get a port (that would fail). It checks that there are no VMs with two ports (and this is the bug reported by customers) and that VMs with ports have both an IPv4 and an IPv6 address.

Please let us know what you think about this.

tacker/sol_refactored/common/lcm_op_occ_.message:
Once in the "FAILED" state, if the LCM operation is successful again, I think LcmOpOcc data of the vnf instance is registered like for example:
```
+-----------+------------------+---------------+-----------+
| id        | operationalState | vnfInstanceId | operation |
+-----------+------------------+---------------+-----------+
| OpOccID_1 | FAILED           | InstID_1      | SCALE     |
| OpOccID_2 | COMPLETED        | InstID_1      | HEAL      |
+-----------+------------------+---------------+-----------+
```
In this situation, DB sync will always be skipped.
I'm sorry if I'm wrong. What do you think?

In the following two cases, DB synchronization is not performed, is it?
1. When there is FAILED_TEMP in operationalState of LcmOpOcc.
2. When the latest operationalState of LcmOpOcc is FAILED.
Yes, I think `FAILED` check should do only for the latest LcmOpOcc if there are multiple LcmOpOccs.
I think it would be better to define a suitable Exception separately.

manila/share/drivers/cephfs/driver.py.message:
I suggest adding a line here about the behavior of this option:

Changes to this configuration option will only affect new resources.
i suggest calling this "set_mode", so it is generic, and default to True here..
this comment makes more sense in the ensure_share method when you will explicitly turn off setting the mode

Unfortunately, this condition is not enough to avoid this bug.

Even if the driver doesn't pass the "mode" to the command, the current implementation of the command defines a default mode of "755" (even if "--mode" is not set!):
https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v16.2.9/src/pybind/mgr/volumes/module.py#L449

This behaviour has been reported here: https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/58432.

Said that, I would say only two "safe" options exist here:
* Fetch current mode as proposed by Victoria in LP.
* Modify `ensure_share` to only call creation if it doesn't exist (this is the patch I deployed in our deployment to temporary workaround the problem until his is fixed)

Thank you for the input - We thought about modifying the ensure_share to call creation only when the share was not already created, but as the end we think that wouldn't be the ideal behavior. If a subvolume no longer exists in ceph, then there is something wrong and it needs to be treated accordingly, so instead, we will do the ensure shares by only ensuring that the export path exists. Please take a look at the newest PS and let us know your thoughts.

Thanks for the response here Luis; i think the latter is a better approach for now. We wanted to be able to avoid the ensure_share call altogether with this driver unless some config changes are made... I don't think the idempotent share creation logic is very helpful to us, atleast on each share service restart.
thanks, as we discussed, it makes sense for the share manager to handle such exceptions and set the share status to "error"

playbooks/haproxy-install.yml.message:
This should follow the pattern of the other roles where we override the defaults when calling them..... something like "vars: haproxy_services: "{{ haproxy_default_services}}" here. Doing it like this would mean there was no need to have anything about `haproxy_preconfigured_services` in the haproxy_server role and it would stay completely generic

I think that this playbook should be the place to resolve the "initial" configuration of haproxy, and any steps needed to bootstrap a fresh deployment for example with LE rather than put any of that into the haproxy_server role itself.

playbooks/os-glance-install.yml.message: why do we not make this simpler and add another play just before this one which targets haproxy_all?

it's not that simple, if we do as you say, we won't be able to access service(for ex. keystone) variables there.

it means that haproxy won't know whether to configure backends to communicate over TLS or not.
During the construction of a list here it would also be a place that you could use `combine` to keep the existing `haproxy_glance_api_service_overrides` variable.

This is the point to use 

  vars:
    haproxy_services: "{{ glance_haproxy_services }}"
    
in order to override the default in the haproxy_server role. It is much better to make this explicit here rather than implicit as it is at the moment, and will make it so that the same name variable `haproxy_services` does not appear in all the group_vars

In order to achieve high availability of Manila Share services, it is recommended to configure host= XXX in the default module to unify hostname when multiple Manila Share nodes are connected to the same storage backend.
   I believe that even in this case, even if there is only one corresponding record in the database services table, it can be deleted at the stop service because in the report_state function, if it finds that the record is missing, a new one will be created[1]

I think we have two other solutions:

1: Add a scheduled task to periodically clean down services.
2: After kill or stop a service, put db.service_destroy into the thread pool for execution. In order not to block the normal flow of kill or stop, Wait 60 seconds (default service_down_time) before executing the db.service_destroy command. If the service detects down after 60 seconds, run the db.service_destroy command; otherwise, do not execute the db.service_destroy command.

how about this? if we worried about disruption for the interval of time

If you have same host name and service name (i.e. manila-share in this case) then there is only one entry in DB for multiple services. Ideally manila-share does not have same host since its host@backend i.e. host = "%s@%s" % (CONF.host, backend)
So we must have "host" field unique to differentiate between services.

I agree that the original issue is reported with the configuration where you have unique services on unique hosts; however, we have documented uses of the configuration for H/A where the "host" configuration is intentionally set to the same value.

I think the solution Haixin proposes could work as well, but is a bit tricky - i.e., we need to figure out how to you identify services that are "down" for a reason rather than "stopped" -- again, we'd add some info to the database perhaps to identify a service that has been stopped for cleanup. Also, would the thread run within the service targeting the same kind of service? if yes, no automatic cleanup happens when you stop all the services of a particular kind.. maybe that's okay - but it's a bit of the situation we have now.

the original issue is not with same host, but different hosts actually. 
consider e.g. manila-scheduler 
1. deployed on host host1 [DB 1 entry of manila-scheduler]
2. deployed on host host2 [DB 2 entries of manila-scheduler]
3. removed from host host1 [DB, still 2 entries of manila-scheduler]

When service manila-scheduler on host1 is stopped/removed, the manila service list should not report it. The reporting of service down based on heartbeat is fine, but reporting of service which does not exist, is wrong. In big clusters where such deployments happens as PODs, old entries in db are reported as DOWN. So we must clear DB entry on service stop and create new on service start.

>but there may be a disruption for the interval of time?
Not as such.  It is made sure that service exist even before "report_state" comes in picture like here https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/service.py#L143
Thanks, removed RFC and ready to review.
before init_host success, the init status could be 'down'. The rpc message cannot be processed until the initialization is successful.  After that, report_state sets the status to up.
ok, changed initial state to 'DOWN'.

I have two more questions:
 
1:if there is only one node, as you said: The 'stopped' service  will never get periodic timer enabled, Does cleanup_services execute on time?

2: if there are two nodes(node01 and node02). both lost connection to backend storage. now the service state is 'down'. admin exec stop service at node01, set state of the service be "stopped",  node02 periodic exec report_state, then found utils.service_is_up(service_ref) if False, then state_catalog['state'] = 'down', will from "stopped" to "down", then cleanup_services skip service_destroy this service.    Is there anything missing in my description?

1. If there is only one node, the stopped service will get periodic timer enabled only when you start it again. Thereafter, it will be 'up' and both report_State and cleanup_services execute on time.

2. If node01 is stopped, it will 'stopped' state while node01 will 'down' state. The periodic timer from service on node02, will delete the stopped i.e. node01 service. It will not change status of node02 service. In cleanup, the service check for all other services under same topic, this helps to cleanup node01 service.

1： that is ok.

2: for example, backend storage is lvm. then node01 and node02 has same entries of service, that is manila@lvm. node01 and node02 share only one record in DB. if we set service "stopped" in node01. Most likely, report_state will be executed first because report_interval < cleanup_interval, After report_state is executed, if utils.service_is_up(service_ref) == False in node02, state of the service will be set from "stopped" to "down", finally  cleanup_services skip service_destroy this service record. That's why I recommend that the service be set to down only when the state is not stopped. how do you think about this?

The service will be 'stopped' when its stopped by admin. Next time when service is up, if its on same host and same binary, it will move to 'up' else it will remain as 'stopped'. The report state, only consider services that are started by start() which will be either up or down. The 'stopped' service will never get periodic timer enabled and then it will be cleanup by cleaup_services.

1. This is what happens today also, the service stopped will remain in DB. The stopped service is marked as stopped and not destroyed. It will be destroyed in next start() call when periodic cleanup executes. And service is only destroyed if its 'stopped' e.g. if it becomes 'up'/'down' it will be not destroyed. 

2. ok, In our case, we set as host=manila@node01 and manila@node02 and so different entries of services. And as per explained scenario, manila@node01 will be deleted once it 'stopped' by periodic callback of service running on manila@node02

since you have single service representing two(or more) nodes, what do you prefer
1) report stopped if all of them stopped i.e. delete entry in cleanup
2) report stopped if either of them stopped i.e. delete entry in cleanup

If you prefer 2), this means there will be no service entry shown even if another node is 'down'(and not stopped). On the other hand service is shown as 'up' if another node is 'up'. I will go with 1. Let me know what suits best for your configuration and I will change accordingly.
ok, fixed

1: that means if only one node, if admin stop service, the service still remain in database? 

2: we all set host=manila in node01 and node02 in manila.conf, then they have same host. for example host is manila@lvm. In this case node01 and node02 share a service record. Then my description above would be valid.

Sorry for the late reply， In my opinion：
i perfer 2), for example There are the following scenarios:

1: Both node01 and node02 are disconnected from the back-end storage. the service is displayed as down if no stop is executed, the service will remain in the database and will not be deleted.

2: Both node01 and node02 are disconnected from the back-end storage. Run stoped on node01. node02 finds that utils.service_is_up(service_ref) == False and the state is stoped. In this case, the value should be stoped instead of down. To ensure cleanup_services can delete this service record smoothly. In my opinion, if all nodes are utils.service_is_up(service_ref) == False, then as long as you execute stoped on any node, you can keep stoped until the record is deleted, rather than being reset to down.

3: node01 works properly, only node02 is disconnected from the storage. Run stoped on node01. node02 finds utils.service_is_up(service_ref) ==True and resets the status from stoped to up。

ironic/api/controllers/v1/node.py.message: What is the use-case for filtering by more than one shard? Is that met by the sharded boolean filter later in this series? If so can we switch to support filtering a single shard and replacing the 'shard_in' filter with a 'shard' filter?
Sorta wanted to also ask ... I don't understand why we wouldn't allow this? What's the argument against? If there's a performance concern; we simply catch the single-shard case and query differently.
I just wanted to hear the complexity/functionality tradeoff, and by the above explanation multi-shard lookup is definitely useful, thanks.

It's a usability thing. We want to enable operators to use shards to scale for anything they need; local scripts that iterate nodes as well as our intended use in nova and networking-baremetal. We should not assume ahead of time that all these cases will scale to the same size. One way to remedy this is to permit, in the API, the ability to request multiple shards. Then, a service or operator script could access multiple shards at the same time.

for example -- (note: all numbers made up; we don't have shard support in nova-compute or networking-baremetal to benchmark yet) -- For my cloud, I need 9 separate Nova compute shards in order to scale properly with a recommended limit of 500 nodes per nova-compute (meaning 4500 nodes total). I then have 9 shards of 500 nodes. It's possible that operators would want to slice this up differently for a different use case, such as updating all nodes in a shard or even, potentially, in networking-baremetal. In these cases, these operators could configure their script or service to query for 3 shards, giving you an effective split of 1/3 instead of 1/9.

specs/approved/active-steps.rst.message:
a small suggestion - trying to reinforce the fact that we already have some of the steps that can be used to update firmware or firmware/BIOS settings, however we are missing a mechanism to run these steps on ACTIVE nodes:

"deployment or cleaning. It would be valuable to provide a mechanism that will allow using existing steps such as updating firmware and changing BIOS settings not only on nodes that are being deployed or cleaned but also on nodes that in ACTIVE state. The same mechanism can be used to support steps that may be only applicable to nodes in ACTIVE state or to execute arbitrary actions."

The probe tests are failing because we are mutating node dicts ! 😭

The probe tests filter node dicts here [1]. But once a node dict (e.g. one of the brain nodes) has been used for a direct client operation than it will be mutated to have use_replication key, which will cause it to mismatch an excluded node i.e. excluded nodes are being included!

I think this is a warning sign that mutating node dicts may not be such a great idea (as opposed to replacing them with annotated versions somewhere early in the request handling path).

So here's what I was concerned about in more detail:

Usually the NodeIter is taking source node dicts from a Ring, and those source node dicts do not have a use_replication item. Then the NodeIter adds use_replication to the dict. In that sense the test is unrealistic in that the NodeIter is being fed source dicts that already have use_replication. I therefore expected line 5429 to change to remove us_replication=False.

However, on reflection, I can see that it is useful to test the case when a custom iter is given to the NodeIter and the source dicts DO have use_replication, because that is allowed by the interface. So let's stick with line 5429 as you have it.

BUT let's actually assert that the NodeIter would *change* use_replication in the source dict when required....

Maybe this test should be called test_iter_nodes_with_replication_network and the one above called test_iter_nodes_without_replication_network

It would be great to have this test scenario added to the previous test so that we cover these vectors:

* custom node_iter had source node dicts with and without the use_replication item

* call to iter_nodes passes a Request with and without a 'x-backend-use-replication-network' header

The interesting scenario that is not yet covered is to pass a request to iter_nodes with a header that causes use_replication to be set to True, when the source dicts already have use_replication=False, and to assert that even when the source_node dicts have use_replication=False, the NodeIter will set use_replication according to the Request headers.

And, ditto, that if source_dicts have use_replication=True but the header has 'x-backend-use-replication-network'=False, then the output dicts will have use_replication=True

openstack/shared_file_system/v2/share_ne.message: This is going to be a list of a different resource type (share network subnets)... So i would suggest commenting this out until we have the other resource implemented

This isn't a valid filter for share networks... Some filters are documented here: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/shared-file-system/?expanded=list-share-networks-with-details-detail#id257

And some aren't documented (we ought to fix that in the manila API reference) - these are the valid filters according to the API code:

"project_id", "all_tenants", "name", "description", "created_since", "created_before", "security_service_id"

[1] https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/7212aa2b7695d27c86e540c3dd1f64925bc056a0/manila/api/v2/share_networks.py#L163-L208

we could translate this to "all_projects".. "project" is what the OpenStack identity service calls "tenants" - however, for legacy reasons, most manila APIs still use the "tenants" terminology

  all_projects='all_tenants'

this won't work. 

The API still expects and parses only "all_tenants", you'll need to add this as a kwarg to do the conversion when specified:

 all_projects='all_tenants'

Wondering if we want to fix this in this way. In upgrade to next release, a new upgrade metadata "supported_kubernetes_versions" is introduced, in order to restrict the upgrade from a specific allowed list of k8s versions. The new change will not rely on patching release N in order to be compatible with N+1 as N+1 there could be a lot of dynamic in N+1 release after release N GA.

Note that I had thought that using inspect was OK since I thought this resulted in same thing for python2 and 3. There is actually another user of inspect.stack() in config/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/openstack/common/rpc/__init__.py: _check_for_lock() .

On python 2.7.5 CentOS, the inspect stack looks like this,
[(<frame object at 0x7ff9b38db590>, '<stdin>', 5, 'A', None, None), (<frame object at 0x7ff9b38e7548>, '<stdin>', 2, 'B', None, None), (<frame object at 0x7ff9b38e73a0>, '<stdin>', 2, 'C', None, None), (<frame object at 0x7ff9b38e71f8>, '<stdin>', 1, '<module>', None, None)]

inspect.stack()[n][3] is of <type str> and comparable

On Python 3.9.2 Debian
[FrameInfo(frame=<frame at 0x7fd2ce3adba0, file '<stdin>', line 3, code A>, filename='<stdin>', lineno=3, function='A', code_context=None, index=None), FrameInfo(frame=<frame at 0x7fd2ce3fe9a0, file '<stdin>', line 2, code B>, filename='<stdin>', lineno=2, function='B', code_context=None, index=None), FrameInfo(frame=<frame at 0x7fd2ce3fe810, file '<stdin>', line 2, code C>, filename='<stdin>', lineno=2, function='C', code_context=None, index=None), FrameInfo(frame=<frame at 0x7fd2ce3fe680, file '<stdin>', line 2, code D>, filename='<stdin>', lineno=2, function='D', code_context=None, index=None), FrameInfo(frame=<frame at 0x7fd2ce3fe4f0, file '<stdin>', line 1, code <module>>, filename='<stdin>', lineno=1, function='<module>', code_context=None, index=None)]

inspect.stack()[n][3] is of <class str> and comparable.

FrameInfo is a named-tuple vs tuple is 2.7.5

No difference in the documentation as well,
https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.stack and https://python.readthedocs.io/en/v2.7.2/library/inspect.html#inspect.stack

Ideally, if we go merging this patch, I'd honestly prefer to hold it until the FeatureFreeze as we can accept it later in the release... or maybe at the beginning of the B release as it costs the least.

-1'ing not because I don't want to change the way it is, but rather because we have other priorities in our backlog to merge before we can move forward with this one.

These sorts of things are a lot of pain for very little gain. IMHO, this is not a sufficiently valuable rename to justify the amount of change and the conflicts as a result. If there was some severe confusion over what is being live migrated or something, then maybe, but I don't think this meets that bar.

I'd prefer we just not do this.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hello!

I have made some changes to Starling X code related to log exception handling when subcloud audit is done. Please, verify the recent code changes and evaluate if the implementation is compliant.

Thanks!

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_mon/cer.message: make this a private method
Done
Also I think it might be clearer to say 'An error occurred during the subcloud audit task.'

How does the exception from _subcloud_audit look like? Does it keep logging the original error message in clear format? 

If not, consider using syntax:

  except Exception as ex:
    self._handle_exception(ex)
    
To allow for better logging of the original exception in 'handle_exception'

The sys.exc_info()[-1] a traceback object that encapsulates the call stack at the point where the exception last occurred. So when an Exception is raised from _subcloud_audit function execution, the _handle_exception will throw the message passed as a parameter along with the traceback from that exception.
Done

I'm not sure why we want to change this to an exception. 
Is there a reason to do this here?

This isn't an "error" condition, since it's quite possible for a subcloud to go offline at any time for whatever reason. Hence the existing log level of warning.
Disagree. An error log is a potential bug. This does not constitute an error condition. Raising it to an error level increases noise in the logs and should be avoided unless there's a good reason.
Ack

The reason this was change as an exception is because the subcloud audit process is aborted after this verification. I do agree that the subcloud offline is a possible scenario and by itself may be considered as a warn level log, but the subcloud audit process being aborted it may be considered as an error level log.
It's not clear to me why we want to raise a new exception in both of these cases. With the existing code, the exception is being handled properly and we are logging the condition.

The reason to raise the exceptions like above is that the messages will be handled by _handle_exception function, that will throw the message along with the callstack traceback. The interpretation of this log as an error is mainly embased in the scenario of aborting the subcloud audit process.

Good coding practice ensures that exceptions are handled as low as possible in the call stack. 

The LOG.exception() call here already ensures the full traceback is logged, so there's no reason to change this code to propagate the exception up the stack. 

In my opinion, you've made the code less clear by introducing this.
Thanks for your collaboration and making your point clear. I've applied changes as you suggested and now the main goal to catch an exception here may be solved.
Similar comment to above for both of these, and the one below.  It seems we are making the exception handling more complex by re-raising a new exception in all these cases.

> The reason to raise the exceptions like above is that the messages will be handled by _handle_exception function, that will throw the message along with the callstack traceback. The interpretation of this log as an error is mainly embased in the scenario of aborting the subcloud audit process.
Same comment as above.
Done
Same comment as above.
Done

cinder/coordination.py.message:
My concern is that 'blocking' goes from being a positional parameter to a keyword-only parameter.  So if anyone is currently calling this as:

  synchronized('name', False)
  
lock_names will be ('name', False) and blocking will be True.  I don't have a better suggestion, though.  I guess mypy should object to such a call as passing the wrong data type to *lock_names.  Until we get everything mypy'd though, I guess the question is what happens when you call

  coordinator.get_lock(False)

not sure if it will barf or create a lock named 'False'.

Currently there is no caller to coordination.synchronized that passes the blocking argument.  I have added an "attention" note on the documentation and made it explicit in the docstring.

If somebody passes just False as the argument it will raise an exception on line 220 since booleans don't have a "format" method.
Not really a list, though.  Maybe say "Arbitrary number of lock names".

I was thinking from the perspective of the code inside the method (where it's always a list), but that is not the right perspective.  It should always be phrased from the method caller's perspective, and from that perspective talking about a list would be confusing.

I'm probably being too picky, but maybe say:

  will reorder the names alphabetically
  
just to make it completely clear that the order in which the arguments are specified is ignored.

this is intentionally reversed from prior condition check?

Yes, It's intentionally reversed. The _check_controller_locked function checks if the active controller is locked and throws an error if it's not. Before, if the user tried to change from duplex to duplex-direct, it would check if the active controller is locked, and that's not possible on a duplex, only on a simplex.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: We should probably mention that the '-f' option allows the overall k8s upgrade process to start if there are non-service-affecting alarms, so it logically makes sense to use the same option to allow each step of the k8s upgrade to proceed.

test plan should be:
-test with no memory alarm and no "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is allowed
-test with memory alarm and no "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is rejected
-test with memory alarm and "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is allowed.

You can manually edit the sysinv DB as well as /etc/fstab and the kubernetes stage2 link to revert back to the 1.23.1 version, that'll save having to reinstall between each test.  Talk to me if you need instructions.
On reflection that may be excessive for such a tiny change.  But you do need to at least test that it allows the kubelet upgrade when there's a platform memory alarm.

This commit title doesn't reflect what the code is actually doing.

More clear as,
Enable kubelet upgrade with force option on AIO-SX

This enables overall k8s upgrade process to start if there are non-service-affecting alarms, such as platform memory.

Should spell out the actual command you are affecting,
system kube-upgrade-start --force v1.19.11

I think you can simplify this down (no need to repeat), we are trying to have close as possible to single line of status and overall testcase.

Test Plan:
PASS: no memory alarm and no "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is allowed
PASS: with memory alarm and no "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is rejected
PASS: with memory alarm and "-f" option, ensure kubelet upgrade is allowed

We already supported *starting* the k8s upgrade process with the "-f" option.  The issue is that "system kube-host-upgrade -f controller-0 kubelet" was not allowed if there is a non-service-affecting alarm, even with the "-f" option.
nit: commit message should not wrap (under 72chars)
Agreed, manually wrap these lines under 72 chars.

This isn't quite accurate.  The way the code is written, for AIO-SX with the -f" option we will enable the k8s kubelet upgrade procedure to start if the system is online and able to accept the command.  This is reasonable because the kubelet upgrade merely involves adjusting mount points so should still be doable with the "-f" option even if the node is in-test/degraded/failed/locked.

For other node types the "-f" option will have no effect because we already only check that the node is online and locked.

octavia/tests/unit/network/drivers/neutr.message: I think that the iter is not necessary when we use side_effect

No, that is not the actual problem here, but thank you for commenting because there is actually a problem here and in other lines that I was not aware of before.

First, I use iter() to create an iterator because network_proxy.ports() returns a generator (which is an implementation of an iterator). That part is correct.

side_effect was used in these tests before, but I should have changed it to return_value. side_effect makes that at each object call it will return the next element. That is not the same as an iterator. Hence, I should not use it. It's not obvious, but it you think it through it makes sense.

manila/scheduler/host_manager.py.message:
Although we pick this statistic from the share driver for each storage pool, manila hasn't _used_ this value in making scheduling decisions so far.. It's possible that administrators can use allocated_capacity_gb in share types and in driver filters and goodness functions if desired. 

Now, with your change, we're falling back to allocated_capacity_gb if backends do not report provisioned_capacity_gb. I agree with this fallback, although i really don't know how this solves the bug reported. 

A huge thing to consider is that the scheduler service supports Active/Active HA - which means that multiple copies of the scheduler service will be running at any given point in time in deployments; if each scheduler process performs this calculation periodically (default: once every minute), it's very wasteful and quite resource intensive. I always hated the way we performed this calculation. :(

Currently, without this change, the calculation occurs _only_ if the pool supports thin provisioning (rationale here is that you don't use provisioned_capacity_gb only when calculating oversubscription ratio). However, with this change, we'll _always_ calculate the allocated_capacity_gb if the backend doesn't report it. This seems wasteful, especially because it is retrieving a ton of information in an un-optimized way from the database to calculate this capacity info -- **every minute**, only to use it in **one place**. 


Instead of doing this, is it possible for us to create a driver resources record in the database, and keep a running tally of the allocated_capacity_gb as provisioning/de-provisioning happens? Its possible to run into race conditions - yes, but, we could periodically check and update these tallies. We just bump up the periodicity of such an update -- do it once every 30 minutes or even an hour -- we should be okay with slight variations in this data; what do you think? We can design this together and present this idea at the PTG - i'm happy to collaborate :)


An alternative would be to go ahead and commit this fallback logic, but definitely do this *only* if the pool supports thin provisioning

Here are some of my understanding, there may be inaccurate places, we can discuss together.
1: allocated_capacity_gb = shares_gb created by manila in openstack A,
   provisioned_capacity_gb = allocated_capacity_gb + shares_gb_created_manually or 
   another manila in openstack B.
   means provisioned_capacity_gb >= allocated_capacity_gb 
   Therefore, if allocated_capacity_gb is reported by the storage back-end,
   manila in openstack A is considered to have exclusive access to the storage
   pool. Otherwise, allocated_capacity_gb is inaccurate if it is not exclusive,
   but it must be accurate if it is counted from the database.
   when calculating oversubscription ratio, we must use provisioned_capacity_gb.
   if provisioned_capacity_gb not reported. but allocated_capacity_gb reported.
   we consider exclusive storage pool, use allocated_capacity_gb instead of 
   provisioned_capacity_gb.
2: total_capacity_gb indicates the actual physical storage capacity of the storage
   pool.
   free_capacity_gb indicates the actual free physical storage capacity of the 
   storage pool.
   used_capacity_gb = total_capacity_gb - free_capacity_gb
   if manila in openstack A exclusive the Storage Pool, then 
   allocated_capacity_gb == provisioned_capacity_gb.
   if not, provisioned_capacity_gb > allocated_capacity_gb.
   if self.thin_provisioning is false.
   used_capacity_gb == provisioned_capacity_gb 
   else used_capacity_gb < provisioned_capacity_gb 
3: about scheduler service supports Active/Active HA, The consume_from_share
   function is executed each time a share is created or extend, in this function
   allocated_capacity_gb and free_capacity_gb must be updated,Suppose 100 1gb  
   shares are created, 50 of which are executed on node 1 and 30 on node 2 and 20 
   on node 3. Since allocated_capacity_gb is maintained in the memory of the 
   scheduling service. As a result, the allocated_capacity_gb values of the three 
   scheduling nodes are inconsistent. This is problematic, so we need to correct it
   in this way.
   so i think no matter storage pool support thin_provisioning, As long as the
   allocated_capacity_gb (non-exclusive storage pool) is not reported, we need to
   calculate and correct it to avoid inconsistent cache values for multiple 
   scheduling services.
4: I prefer to count allocated_capacity_gb from the database through a scheduled 
   task loop. To reduce system performance consumption.

magnumclient/common/utils.py.message: How do we achieve backwards compatibility?

Thanks for this. From testing, this works on fcos37 and k8s v1.24.

I am hoping to get consensus on what is the supported version in the next meeting. Then we can make CI do that. It seems like FCOS37 and v1.24 is achievable.

with kubectl 1.26 i also needed to add:
 interactiveMode: IfAvailable
at the "command:" level. Does it work without it?

This change means Kubernetes 1.10 and earlier won't work, as `v1beta1` was added in Kubernetes 1.11 which was released in June 2018.

How far back should we try and maintain compatibility?

According to the PTG survey( https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/oct2022-ptg-magnum ), the main contributors are not using Kubernetes 1.10 or lower.

(I'm keen to see Magnum with better backwards compatibility for labels like Calico, which the manifests need to change (but then break older versions). I'm not sure this is such a case, is it? How do we define how far back we should support?)
That's fine - but yes, we should have a process on defining what Kubernetes releases should be supported in Antelope (and have a CI on testing them).

were you using v1beta1 or v1? from [1]

 The user.exec.interactiveMode field is optional in client.authentication.k8s.io/v1beta1 and required in client.authentication.k8s.io/v1

The other thing is kubectl version skew is +1/-1. So we can make this work for API 1.24 first (so only support using kubectl 1.23-1.25), and have subsequent patches for kube api 1.25 and 1.26.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/authentication/#input-and-output-formats

zuul/model.py.message: There are three places we call pipeline.state.refresh; all in scheduler.py.  And in all three places we do hold the pipeline lock.  Did I miss something?
Yep, you are right. Sorry missed that.

I think we must not create the pipeline state when refreshing the pipeline in read-only mode. Otherwise we are re-creating a similar race condition that we are trying to fix (I could imagine that this is also the reason for the test failures).

Assuming the above question about whether we hold the pipeline lock is resolved such that we do, then this is safe.  The important thing is the lock, not "read-only".  It's confusing, so I put a comment in for that.

This is not always the case. We also refresh the pipeline change list during tenant trigger event processing and when gathering connection cache keys during cleanup w/o holding the pipeline lock.

In those cases we don't want to create the initial change list. Maybe we also need a `read_only` flag here.

That's true, I missed those two cases.  We do need to handle them, possibly with a flag (but probably not "read_only" since that's confusing) and in that case, we should raise an exception that we catch in the retry method.

I think the name of the exception is a bit misleading. When we get a `NoNodeError` we don't know if the pipeline was not initialized or if the change list is currently in the process of being updated (sharded zkobject).

Looks like we stop setting the layout_uuid on the PipelineState here as we get it from the pipeline object in _lateInitData instead.

Also looks like create() is not a common pattern to all the zkobjects that we're changing semantics for. This method is only on the two classes modified in this change.
Note this was mostly written for my own understanding and for the hopes of helping anyone else reviewing the change. Doesn't call out something that needs updating.

In refresh we note that this deserialize() path is used instaed. But unlike refresh() we don't call _set() to set the layout_uuid on this object. And we don't write out the contents to zookeeper. Should these two be equivalent considering one is taking precedence over the other?

I'm guessing we may not always have a write lock when deserializing which makes that unsafe. This leads me to wonder when we do actually write back to zookeeper for this object? Also, any concern with multiple schedulers passing through this block without a lock?

I'm not seeing a reference to layout_uuid in refresh, so I'm having trouble parsing this.

We write to ZK at the end of every pipeline processing (or if we call internalCreate).
I was missing the refresh -> load -> deserialize call path in my head. We end up _set()ing the return value of this call up the stack. THat will set layout_uuid from the _lateInitData() call.
Nit, might be more defensive to default to false here and explicitly indicate the lock is held when it is rather than the opposite.

The normal pattern is to hold the lock, so it's designed for that.  I get where you're coming from, but I don't want to flip the pattern so we have to do extra work when we have the lock.  We should *always* have the lock, and in the one or two places where we decided it's okay not to, we should be really careful and explicit about it.  I don't want us thinking that the default is working with it unlocked because it is very much not safe.

zuul/scheduler.py.message:
I think it's not safe to assume that the pipeline is not yet initialized when we get a `ZKObjectNotInitializedError` aka. `NoNodeError` (see my comment in model.py).

Continuing here in case of error might also lead to the cleanup of cached changes that are still relevant (if they are also older than `max_age=2h`).

Agreed.  I was hoping to improve this case, as well as the other one below.  But I can't find a way to distinguish "uninitialized" from "write in progress" without significantly more complexity, so I think we'll have to live with the current guarantees (or lack thereof).

This is great! I'm quite excited to be able to use this feature in the future. I left a few inline comments.

Besides those the only thing I think that's really missing here is a release note for this new feature and also maybe expanding some of the testing to cover some negative cases with incorrectly formatted input (related to some of my questions in `config.py`) and to see how things respond to invalid subsections.
Thanks, Matthew, for iterating on the syntax with me!

reno/config.py.message:
Do you think we should be doing

```
if len(entry) == 3:
   ...
elif len(entry) > 3:
   raise

```

here instead. I just worry this will let someone pass in incorrectly formatted configuration like: `['features', 'New Features', ['features_command_line', 'Command Line'], ['features_library', 'Library']]` which would pass through this and result in incorrect output

I think so. In fact, I accidentally used the syntax you're worried about in my test! It took me a minute to realize I was missing the outer [].

Generally, I think this could use more eager data validation. I only wasn't sure the convention on how defensive to be—we didn't validate this config option before. 

Concretely, it seems like in most places we only log warnings, but there are a few TODOs to convert to errors. So, here, I think I should error for invalid input?

Yeah, I think erroring on invalid input here is best. Especially since the new syntax is easy to make a mistake with, having a clear error message earlier would be better for users trying to set custom subheadings.

We can always circle back and add better input validation on the other options too. I think that would be good in general.
Implemented. Although, I don't proactively check that a) `sections` is a list to begin with, and b) each entry within `sections` is a list

Just a question, I'm wondering if we can support more than 1 level of nesting here? I think for most use cases and in general just starting with 2 levels of hierarchy is more than sufficient. By itself this gives us a lot more flexibility in building release notes. But I'm just curious what this would look like if we wanted to support more levels of nesting. `docutils` supports an arbitrary number of levels (but html output will limit us to 6 total levels in the output document in practice).

Huh..Good to know, thanks.

It seems possible to make this support arbitrary nesting, e.g. converting my parsing algorithm to be recursive. But, it will make that code more complex to read and the user documentation more complex, as well. A syntax like `[features, Features], [[sub, Sub], [[more_sub, More Sub]]]]` is pretty hard to read.

Instead, if we want arbitrary nesting, I think I'd encourage a syntax like `[name, My Title, 1]`, where 1 represents the nesting level. Then we have a flat list of sections. Much simpler syntax.
This is now implemented. I think it's much simpler and more flexible if we want even deeper nesting in the future.
I don't think we can. Per https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html#sections, my understanding is that ^ is already the lowest level of subsections available.

Heh, that section of the sphinx docs is very poorly laid out, I've made the same mistake many times myself (until I had to dig deeper into how it worked at one point), having the example from the python style guide there makes it seem like there is a fixed hierarchy. But, before that list of symbols from the Python style guide the text says:

```
Section headers (ref) are created by underlining (and optionally overlining) the section title with a punctuation character, at least as long as the text:

=================
This is a heading
=================

Normally, there are no heading levels assigned to certain characters as the structure is determined from the succession of headings
```

Then after they list the python style guides suggested section headers it says:

```
Of course, you are free to use your own marker characters (see the reST documentation), and use a deeper nesting level, but keep in mind that most target formats (HTML, LaTeX) have a limited supported nesting depth.
```

The `reST documentation` it is referring to is: https://docutils.sourceforge.io/docs/ref/rst/restructuredtext.html#sections
I wonder if we can use the sphinx directive here to make this a warning or note box? I'm not sure this gets passed to sphinx intact though so it might not work.

I'm not sure how I'd do this. Although note that warning has always been a problem. The new syntax for subsections make that more obvious, and I moved the warning to a dedicated paragraph to make it more clear. So maybe it's fine as is?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hello,

Can you please add in the commit message, the link to the spec that defines this alternative option?

Thank you.

Hmmm, not sure if there's a spec reference but I noticed this when cloud-init on Linux would accept this meta-data whereas cloudbase-init on Windows didn't:

  instance-id: my-instance-id
  local-hostname: my-host-name
  public-keys:
    - ssh-rsa ...

Specifically, here's what happens with cloud-init in a debian nocloud image:

1. ssh is listed in cloud_init_modules and one of the things that module does is setup SSH keys for the default user [here](https://github.com/canonical/cloud-init/blob/02202954c65a7a1cdb9b28703bd0af01edd0e091/cloudinit/config/cc_ssh.py#L338)
2. If the config allows it (which it does by default), it gets those keys via asking the "cloud" provider in use (nocloud in this case) [here](https://github.com/canonical/cloud-init/blob/02202954c65a7a1cdb9b28703bd0af01edd0e091/cloudinit/config/cc_ssh.py#L327)
3. Since the NoCloud datasource doesn't override it, that's a call to the `DataSource` base class's `get_public_ssh_keys` method [here](https://github.com/canonical/cloud-init/blob/3b8b46926b7ef46ac0ee73d51285dd274906e4f3/cloudinit/sources/__init__.py#L651)
4. As expected it's grabbing the "public-keys" key from the metadata and then tries to normalize it with a call to `normalize_pubkey_data` [here](https://github.com/canonical/cloud-init/blob/3b8b46926b7ef46ac0ee73d51285dd274906e4f3/cloudinit/sources/__init__.py#L901)
5. That's where you see similar logic as I added to cloudbase-init here, checking if the given pubkey data is a list [here](https://github.com/canonical/cloud-init/blob/3b8b46926b7ef46ac0ee73d51285dd274906e4f3/cloudinit/sources/__init__.py#L910-L911)

Interestingly enough, looking closer at this it seems like it wouldn't actually work with the `{'public-keys': {'0': {'openssh-key': '...'}}}` format at all.

and have it create a secret with or without consumers.  You can then call this helper method not just in the new tests - but also refactor some of the old tests to reduce code duplication.

You can also move this helper method to the top of the class (ie. before the test methods)
